title: Can the new iPad Pro 12.9 replace a laptop? - Quora

response.answer_text: Well… not quite. I guess some folks would say ‘yes, absolutely’ and some ‘not a chance’, with various interpretations of your use cases. However, to me, ‘capability to organize files effectively, move files through USBs, print documents and such’ doesn’t sound like a particularly complete description of what I expect a student to want to do. What software do you anticipate using (if you know yet)? What subjects will you study at what level? Does the college where you will study have any advice about whether you will need a laptop? I have had an iPad Pro 12.9 for over a year and used it for an hour or more a day for a ton of different tasks. I love it - it is really, really good - and justifiably expensive. I also have two high-end laptops (work and personal ) which I use around seven hours a day or more, mostly for work, again, widely varied tasks. It’s been 20+ years since I was a student, but three or four years of study (assuming you’re about to start an undergraduate degree course) will involve countless activities for which you’d want a good computing device. A laptop is much more flexible. There is just so much more you can do with one than an iPad. For niche, specific tasks that the iPad plus a good app does well (such as taking handwritten notes, drawing, a portable reading device and web browser), the iPad is much better than a laptop. For a much wider range of tasks (including writing and editing large documents - something I imagine all students need to do a lot), a laptop is either much better in my opinion, or is the only one which is even capable of doing the job, because the software for that job is only available on a laptop, or the iOS Apps which do the job have a much reduced set of functionality. You can also get a really nice laptop for the same price as a relatively small-storage iPad Pro without cellular, and have money to spare for some software. If you were thinking about getting the biggest iPad Pro with cellular (which is what I chose), then for the same price you can get an absolutely brilliant laptop - powerful and light - which will easily last your entire course and then some, and a docking station, a decent monitor, keyboard and mouse to use when you’re working at your desk - much nicer for those loooooong writing/study sessions. So, no, I don’t think an iPad can really replace a laptop for most of us. It’s getting really, really close, and if you had the option to have both, I would. But if you can only have one, have a laptop.

With the pending release of iOS11 the answer is YES*. But notice that yes has an asterisk. iOS 11 is a significant change to iOS. It brings visible sharable files, and system-wide drag and drop. This means that users whose work requires acting on files or users who need workflows which bounce data between different applications, will find everything becomes much easier and more intuitive. For those who do this sort of thing, iOS 11 iPad is going to be ideal. Now for the asterisk part. *However… There are people who develop software, or rely on all sorts of specialised apps and plugins and various modifications to the system. These people will never be satisfied with the constraints of a safe OS. They need a desktop style OS, and all the instability and mutability that goes with it. For them anything less than this is not a “real” computer. I suspect there is a bit of bias at work in estimating how big these two groups are. A lot of people who live and breathe in computer-land would estimate that 90% of users absolutely need desktop features, and only about 10% could manage with a restricted machine. I would dispute those numbers. My guess is that in the real world, about 95% of people would be totally happy with the benefits of a safe os and perhaps only small number of computer specialists need the features of desktop OS. I don’t think the desktop PC operating system is going away. But I think the majority of users can manage without the risk. And there is one other reason why we should avoid using PC OSes…

It depends. I have an iPad Pro 10.5 and I love it. I use it everyday for many different tasks: watching videos, emails, social media, web browsing, online shopping, etc. I can even use it for scanning documents and maybe some light word processing and Excel, but nothing too heavy. My iPad works great on the content consumption tasks (emails, social media, etc.), but runs into problems when I want to actually to produce something more complex. So, my answer to this would be that if your sole purpose is content consumption and that’s what you use your laptop for, then, yes, the iPad can probably replace it. But as soon as you get to the more complex tasks, then you need a PC. For most people, I would say that they could probably live with just an iPad as most computer-related tasks fall in the content consumption category. For those heavy-duty users who need to actually produce something, then, no, it cannot replace a laptop. Apple needs to add more features (mouse support, better file management system, etc.) to iOS to really be considered a PC replacement.

It’s getting close, but no. USB is out. There is no USB Mass Storage Driver. Printing is possible, but only with AirPrint. Organizing files is not really a thing. You may have more of that in iOS 11, but right now it’s all cloud-storage focused. iPad still focuses on consuming media, not producing it. For drawings and office documents, iOS 11 steps forward, but cannot replace a laptop unless you alter your workflow to exclude USB drives, focus on cloud storage, and stop thinking about file hierarchies and instead rely on tags and search.

It really depends on what programs you need. If you're a liberal arts major and just need a word processor and a web browser, there's a very good chance that an iPad with an external keyboard could be all you need. Your needs could be served today with Dropbox (or other cloud storage), and with iOS 11 and the Files App you may not even need that. There are flash drives available with a lightning connector and a USB connector that work with iPads. Most recent printers have AirPrint support so you can print from an iPad. I regularly multitask on my 9.7″ iPad Pro (though YouTube requires a YouTube red subscription for that feature), so you'll comfortably be able to have two or more things open at once on a 12.9″ model. As a college student you'll likely have access to a computer lab if there is a task that an iPad can't do.

I think you can, but recommend you proceed carefully. Depending on the direction you are going in school, some applications in their App form may not exist or be where they need to be compared to their Mac/PC versions. iOS 11 has the Files App to handle your primary need (keep in mind iCloud Drive does this already), services like iCloud Drive/OneDrive/Google Drive make moving files via USB obsolete, and printing has been standard in iOS for a long time. Good Luck.

The file movement problem can be countered via cloud or a WIFI harddisk like the seagate wireless plus.

As others have commented USB is out but WiFi file transfer is easy and cloud storage works well too. Internal storage is fixed and limited to the model you buy. There is no microSD expansion slot. And you are still confined to apps in Apple's walled garden. There are no BitTorrent apps and no apps to download video from YouTube, Vimeo and etc. Yes, there are work-arounds but they are clumsy. You should consider similar competitive products from Samsung before buying.
